repnme.cdata!:
Romania - Telecommunications Reform and
            Privatization Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Telecommunications
            Reform and Privatization Support Project for Romania were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was negligible to low, the Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: 1) in the telecom sector and in the
            Romania Telecommunication Reform and Privatization Project,
            where the frontier of technology is moving at a rapid pace,
            it is advisable to build a degree of flexibility into
            project design and supervision to accommodate at least some
            of the new applications that may become possible during
            implementation; 2) project design of telecom projects such
            as the Romania Telecommunication Reform and Privatization
            Project involving equipment procurement and installation
            should give more attention to risks in project cost
            estimation and assessment of bidders for the supply and
            installation of telecom equipment. Supervision should help
            ensure that appointed project management consultants are
            fully utilized; and 3) while it is important for the Bank to
            focus on technical assistance aspects of telecom projects,
            such as support for training and for the development of the
            policy and regulatory frameworks, it is also essential to
            ascertain potential support for such components from other
            international financial institutions and agencies to
            eliminate duplication of resources, as occurred in the
            Romania Telecommunication Reform and Privatization Project.

Romania - Telecommunications Reform and

            Reform and Privatization Support Project

10458544.trustfund:
TF020290-IRISH CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF022620-CANADIAN CTF FOR E. & C.
            EUROPE & THE CIS,TF025227-PHRD-TELECOMMUNICATIONS PROJECT,TF031143-ROMANIA - TELECOMMUNICATIONS SECTOR,TF034975-ROMANIA - TELECOMMUNICATIONS,TF038779-ROMANIA - SUPERVISION OF

repnme.cdata!:
Romania - Telecommunications Reform and
            Privatization Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings covey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, achieved through
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank and Borrower.
            Regardless of success, the following are some lessons
            experienced through the project implementation. It is
            reinforced once again that stability of policy, and agency
            structure contributes to project achievement. Despite a
            seemingly country policy development structure at appraisal,
            the subsequent government's different arrangements,
            were a contributing factor for considerable time and
            momentum losses. The issue of suitability of new agencies to
            perform regulatory functions is one of the lessons that, in
            retrospect, the project should have given equal
            consideration to the establishment of a new agency - which
            would work in close collaboration with the technical agency
            - to perform those functions. It is important to note that a
            competent spectrum management, and monitoring system is
            necessary for an expanding, modern telecom sector, since it
            provided support to the expansion of wireless services,
            essential during a period of rapid growth in the use of the
            spectrum. Another reinforcement is the importance of close
            donor coordination, key to reform progress, ensuring that no
            duplication of effort occurred, and facilitating provision
            of timely advice. On the other hand, the availability of
            grant assistance from the other agencies reduced the
            utilization of the project's technical assistance.
